entry.title: Mode Connectivity
entry.content:
Let \(w_1\) and \(w_2\) be two sets of weights corresponding to two neural networks independently trained by minimizing any specified loss \(\mathcal{L}(w)\) (like the cross-entropy loss), and the net space is net. Moreover, we could let \(\phi_{ heta}(t):[0,1] ightarrow\) net be a continuous piece-wise smooth parametric curve connecting \(w_1\) and \(w_2\), with parameters \( heta\), such that \(\phi_{ heta}(0) = w_1\) and \(\phi_{ heta}(1) = w_2\). To find a low-loss and high-accuracy path between \(w_1\) and \(w_2\), we can find the set of parameters \( heta\) that minimizes the expectation over a uniform distribution on the curve, \(\hat \ell( heta)\):

egin{equation} \label{eq1} \hat \ell( heta)=\int_{0}^{1}\mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(t))q_{ heta}(t)dt=E_{t \sim q_{ heta}(t)}\mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(t)), \end{equation}

where the \(q_ heta(t)\) is the distribution for sampling the models on the path indexed by t. However, stochastic gradients of \(\hat \ell( heta)\) in \eqref{eq1} are generally intractable since \(q_{ heta}(t)\) depends on \( heta\). Therefore one can choose a more computationally tractable loss

egin{equation} \label{eq2} \ell( heta)=\int_{0}^{1} \mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(t))dt=E_{t \sim U(0,1)} \mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(t)), \end{equation}

where \(U(0,1)\) is the uniform distribution in the interval \([0,1]\). The difference between \eqref{eq1} and \eqref{eq2} is that the former is an expectation of the loss \(\mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(t))\) with respect to a uniform distribution on the curve, while \eqref{eq2} is an expectation with respect to an uniform distribution on \(t\in[0,1]\).

To minimize \(\ell( heta)\), at each iteration one can sample \(\hat t\) from the uniform distribution \(U(0,1)\) and make a gradient step for $ heta$ with respect to the loss \(\mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(\hat t))\). This means that we would use \( abla_ heta \mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(\hat t))\) to estimate the true gradient of \(\ell( heta)\),

egin{equation} abla_ heta \mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(\hat t)) acksimeq E_{t \sim U(0, 1)} abla_ heta \mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(t))= abla_ heta E_{t \sim U(0, 1)} \mathcal{L}(\phi_{ heta}(t))= abla_ heta \ell( heta). \end{equation}

We can choose the Bezier curve as the basic parametric function to characterize the parametric curve \(\phi_ heta(t)\). And We could initialize \( heta\) with \( rac{1}{2}(w_p+w_c)\). A Bezier curve provides a convenient parametrization of smooth paths with given endpoints. For instance, a qadratic Bezier curve \(\phi_{ heta}(t)\) with endpoints \(w_1\) and \(w_2\) is given by

egin{equation} \phi_{ heta}(t) = (1 -t)^2 w_1 + 2t(1-t) heta + t^2 w_2,~~ 0 \le t \le 1. \end{equation}
